dataset_1.label: dataset
values: {"display":"Quota","value":"-- load the quota dataset \nq = load \"simha__Quota_Region1\";\n\n -- We want just the 2017 quota \n  q = filter q by 'Year' == \"2017\"; q = group q by 'Employee';\n\n -- project the owner and their quota \n q = foreach q generate 'Employee' as 'Employee', sum('Quota') as 'sum_Quota';\n\n -- sort the results alphabetically by owner \nq = order q by 'Employee' asc;","chart":"vbar","reflinelabel":"100%","reflinecolor":"rgb(9, 26, 62)","reflinevalue":6000000}

{"display":"Amount Won","value":"-- load the opportunity dataset\n q = load \"simha__Wave_Sample_Opportunities3\"; \n\n-- We want just the 2017 data and the won opportunities \nq = filter q by date('Close_Date_Year', 'Close_Date_Month', 'Close_Date_Day') in [dateRange([2017,1,1], [2017,12,31])]; \nq = filter q by 'Stage' == \"08 - Closed Won\";\n q = group q by 'Account_Owner'; \n\n -- project the sum of amount for each owner \nq = foreach q generate 'Account_Owner' as 'Account_Owner', sum('Amount') as 'sum_Amount'; \n\n -- sort the results alphabetically by owner \n q = order q by 'Account_Owner' asc; q = limit q 2000;","chart":"vbar","reflinelabel":"100%","reflinecolor":"rgb(9, 26, 62)","reflinevalue":3000000}

{"display":"Percent Attained","value":"-- load the opportunity dataset \nopt = load \"simha__Wave_Sample_Opportunities3\"; \n\n -- we just want 2017 data and won opportunities \n opt = filter opt by date('Close_Date_Year', 'Close_Date_Month', 'Close_Date_Day') in [dateRange([2017,1,1], [2017,12,31])]; \nopt = filter opt by 'Stage' == \"08 - Closed Won\"; \n\n -- load the quota dataset \n quo = load \"simha__Quota_Region1\"; \n\n -- we just want 2017 data \n quo = filter quo by 'Year' == \"2017\"; \n\n -- cogroup the two datasets \natt = group opt by 'Account_Owner', quo by 'Employee'; \n\n -- calculate the percent attained for each owner \n att = foreach att generate opt.'Account_Owner' as 'Owner', sum(opt.'Amount')/sum(quo.'Quota') as 'percent attained';","chart":"hbar","reflinelabel":"100%","reflinecolor":"rgb(9, 26, 62)","reflinevalue":1}

parameters.text:
Cogroup also helps you compare values within a single dataset! For example, load a stream filtered for last year, another for this year, then cogroup the streams so you can do math across both.

Cogroup accounts with events to see the number of visits to each. Combine accounts with open cases to see which may be at risk. You can do left, right, and full outer cogrouping, too. The options are endless!
Load the quota dataset (right stream) and filter for 2017.
So, you want to work on data from multiple, related datasets? Or you want to show the same data two different ways in one chart? That's going to require some SAQL! Let's jump in and start cogrouping!
att = foreach att generate opt.'Account_Owner' as 'Owner', sum(opt.'Amount')/sum(quo.'Quota') as 'percent attained';"

They say you can't have it all. But they aren't using cogroup. Use cogroup to combine data from two or more streams (sets of data) into a single stream. You can't do that using explorer alone. 

This example shows how cogroup combines two datasets by matching fields of account owner and employee. Once combined, you can calculate attainment. Looks like Harold Campbell needs to up his game....

Tip: Remember that you need to add datasets to the dashboard before you can use them in SAQL. Simply add a chart, then remove the widget.

Note: A cogroup isn't a join as you might think of in SQL. Cogrouping groups, then joins the matching groups—not the original records, which would be a "proper" join. If you want that, use union.
Cogroup the left and right streams by related fields! (This is inner cogrouping.)

quo = load \"Quota_Region1\"; 
quo = filter quo by 'Year' == \"2017\";

Look at the SAQL Query section below: we load and filter each stream, cogroup by key fields, then calculate.

The opt and quo streams are brought together into a new stream named att, matched by the fields Account_Owner and Employee:

att = cogroup opt by 'Account_Owner', quo by 'Employee'; 

Bonus! We added a reference line from the Chart Properties panel to show the 100% target.

Tip: Though group could be used instead of cogroup, the convention is to use cogroup when you have multiple streams.
att = cogroup opt by 'Account_Owner', quo by 'Employee';
Toggle and see for yourself: Here, we've got quota numbers in one dataset, opportunity data in another, and we're using SAQL cogroup function to calculate and chart quota attainment.
Calculate attainment percentage for each account owner.

opt = filter opt by date('Close_Date_Year', 'Close_Date_Month', 'Close_Date_Day') in [dateRange([2017,1,1], [2017,12,31])]; 
opt = filter opt by 'Stage' == \"08 - Closed Won\";
